Introduction

Mitochondrial myopathies are genetic disorders that impair aerobic glycolysis in mitochondria.  Highly metabolic tissues (eg, brain, skeletal muscle) are primarily affected, and patients can have multisystemic symptoms.  The most common mitochondrial myopathies are mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS), myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fiber (MERRF), and Leigh syndrome (subacute necrotizing encephalomyelopathy).

Pathogenesis



Mitochondria are organelles that efficiently generate ATP, the primary source of energy for the cell, through a process known as oxidative phosphorylation (ie, aerobic metabolism).  Most human cells contain hundreds of mitochondria in order to generate sufficient ATP for cellular function.  A notable exception is mature red blood cells, which lack mitochondria and therefore produce ATP via anaerobic glycolysis exclusively.  Impaired mitochondrial function results in an energy deficit that leads to cellular dysfunction, particularly in highly metabolic tissues (eg, brain, skeletal muscle).



Mitochondria contain their own genetic material, known as mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA).  Unlike nuclear DNA (nDNA), mtDNA exists as a circular chromosome (ie, nucleoid) that encodes 13 proteins required for aerobic glycolysis.  However, more than 17,000 proteins are required for mitochondrial function.  The remaining proteins are encoded in nDNA, synthesized in the cytosol, and transported into the mitochondria.  Therefore, the pathogenesis of mitochondrial myopathies can involve mutations in mtDNA or nDNA.  In either case, these mutations impair mitochondrial function, which is most apparent in highly metabolic tissues.



Modes of inheritance differ among mtDNA and nDNA, with clinically significant implications for patients with mitochondrial myopathies.  In contrast to the Mendelian inheritance patterns (eg, autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, X-linked) seen in nDNA mutations, mtDNA mutations follow a maternal inheritance pattern in which male and female offspring inherit all mtDNA from the mother (

figure 1
).  Therefore, although male offspring can inherit an mtDNA mutation, they cannot pass the mutation to future offspring.



In addition, mtDNA is unique because of heteroplasmy, in which mitochondria with normal and mutant genomes coexist within the same cell (

figure 2
).  Cells that contain more mutant copies than normal copies are more likely to be impaired than those that contain fewer mutant copies than normal copies.  Furthermore, the random distribution of mitochondria during mitosis and/or meiosis results in variable amounts of normal and mutant mitochondria among daughter cells.  A minimum number of mutant mitochondria is required for cellular, tissue, and organ dysfunction to occur, which is referred to as the threshold effect.  The threshold varies by tissue type, with highly metabolic tissues having the lowest threshold.  Therefore, presenting clinical features typically involve these tissues.

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation for each mitochondrial myopathy varies depending on the underlying mutation and the quantity of mutant mitochondria.  Generally, presentation includes neurologic symptoms (eg, developmental delay, seizures, stroke-like episodes, headaches, ataxia, hearing loss) and muscular symptoms (eg, myalgias, ophthalmoplegia, fatigue, myoclonus, cardiac conduction abnormalities).  The most common mitochondrial myopathies include:

Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS)



Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS) presents in early childhood with stroke-like episodes (eg, hemiparesis, hemianopia, cortical blindness), migraine-like headaches, seizures, myopathy (eg, progressive proximal muscle weakness, myalgias), hearing loss, and lactic acidosis (due to impaired aerobic glycolysis).  Brain lesions, which are the result of defective mitochondrial energy production, are referred to as "stroke-like" because they do not correspond to specific vascular territories.  Over time, recurrent stroke-like episodes lead to progressive neurodegeneration and dementia.

Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers (MERRF)



Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fiber (MERRF) presents in childhood with myoclonus, seizures, ataxia, and myopathy.  Though less common, other features include optic atrophy, hearing loss, peripheral neuropathy (eg, sensory, sensorimotor), spasticity, and cardiomyopathy with conduction abnormalities.

Leigh syndrome (subacute necrotizing encephalomyelopathy)



Leigh syndrome (subacute necrotizing encephalomyelopathy) is characterized by bilateral necrotizing lesions in the basal ganglia, thalamus, brainstem, and spinal cord.  The condition typically presents in infancy or early childhood with developmental delay, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia (ie, extraocular muscle weakness), seizures, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes.

Differential diagnosis



  • Muscular dystrophies (eg, Duchenne, Becker):  Present with progressive proximal muscle weakness; however, neurologic symptoms (eg, developmental delay, seizures) are not expected.
  • Myasthenia gravis:  Presents with episodic muscle weakness (eg, ptosis, ophthalmoplegia) that worsens with activity and improves with rest.  Neurologic symptoms do not occur.
  • Glycogen storage diseases:  Can cause exercise intolerance (eg, fatigue, muscle weakness, myalgias) that may improve after a short period of continuous activity (ie, "second wind" phenomenon); the CNS is generally not affected.

Diagnosis



Because of the broad phenotypic heterogeneity and multisystem involvement, the diagnosis of mitochondrial myopathies requires a high index of suspicion and integration of clinical, laboratory, radiographic, and genetic findings.  Diagnostic evaluation begins with a thorough history and physical examination.  A family history of multisystem disease with maternal inheritance (ie, no male-to-male transmission) is highly suspicious for a mitochondrial disorder.  However, mutations in nDNA that affect mitochondrial function can demonstrate an autosomal recessive or dominant inheritance pattern.  Additional diagnostic evaluation includes:



  • Laboratory testing:  Serum lactate and creatine kinase are often elevated.  Muscle biopsy may demonstrate ragged red fibers (accumulation of abnormal mitochondria resulting in muscle fibers of irregular size and shape) with modified Gomori trichrome stain (
    image 1
    ), but muscle biopsy is generally performed only when genetic testing is not diagnostic.
  • Imaging:  MRI of the brain is typically performed in patients with neurologic symptoms.  Findings include generalized demyelination patterns, bilateral necrotizing lesions in Leigh syndrome, stroke-like lesions in MELAS, and other nonspecific findings.
  • Genetic testing:  Nuclear and/or mitochondrial genetic sequencing may be performed, depending on the suspected mitochondrial myopathy.

Management and prognosis



Management is generally supportive with a multidisciplinary approach.  Nutritional supplements (eg, riboflavin, creatine, B-complex vitamins) may be considered to support mitochondrial function in some patients, although more research is needed to demonstrate clinical improvement.  In addition, physical and occupational therapy can help preserve motor function, and genetic counseling should be considered for patients and their family members.



The prognosis is variable, depending on the underlying genetic mutation and degree of heteroplasmy, but most mitochondrial myopathies are associated with significant morbidity and mortality.

Summary



Mitochondrial myopathies are genetic disorders that impair aerobic glycolysis in mitochondria.  Highly metabolic tissues (eg, brain, skeletal muscle) are primarily affected, and patients can present with multisystemic symptoms.  Diagnosis requires a high index of suspicion and integration of clinical, laboratory, radiographic, and genetic findings.  Management is supportive, and morbidity and mortality are high.
